affiliations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research

children.value: Within this notebook, we will cover:
What is gridding and why is it important?
An overview of gridding with Py-ART
How to choose a gridding routine
Gridding multiple radars to the same grid

import os
import warnings

import cartopy.crs as ccrs
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


import pyart
from pyart.testing import get_test_data

warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')

data.name: stdout
data.text:
## You are using the Python ARM Radar Toolkit (Py-ART), an open source
## library for working with weather radar data. Py-ART is partly
## supported by the U.S. Department of Energy as part of the Atmospheric
## Radiation Measurement (ARM) Climate Research Facility, an Office of
## Science user facility.
##
## If you use this software to prepare a publication, please cite:
##
##     JJ Helmus and SM Collis, JORS 2016, doi: 10.5334/jors.119

children.value: What is gridding and why is it important?

children.label: What is gridding and why is it important?

children.value: Radar data, by default, is stored in a
, with the data coordinates stored as an angle (ranging from 0 to 360 degrees with 0 == North), and a radius from the radar, and an elevation which is the angle between the ground and the ground.
This format can be challenging to plot, since it is scan/radar specific. Also, it can make comparing with model data, which is on a lat/lon grid, challenging since one would need to
the model daa cartesian coordinates to polar/antenna coordiantes.
Fortunately, PyART has a variety of gridding routines, which can be used to
grid your data to a Cartesian grid
. Once it is in this new grid, one can easily slice/dice the dataset, and compare to other data sources.

Gridding is essential to combining multiple data sources (ex. multiple radars), and comparing to other data sources (ex. model data). There are also decisions that are made during the gridding process that have a large impact on the regridded data - for example:
What resolution should my grid be?
Which interpolation routine should I use?
How smooth should my interpolated data be?

While there is not always a right or wrong answer, it is important to understand the options available, and document which routine you used with your data! Also - experiment with different options and choose the best for your use case!
An overview of gridding with Py-ART

children.label: An overview of gridding with Py-ART

children.value: Let’s dig into the regridding process with PyART!
Read in and Visualize a Test Dataset

children.label: Read in and Visualize a Test Dataset

children.value: Let’s start with the same file used in the previous notebook (
), which is a radar file from Northern Oklahoma.
Let’s plot up quick look of reflectivity, at the lowest elevation scan (closest to the ground)
As mentioned before, the dataset is currently in the
measured as distance from the radar

children.label: Setup our Gridding Routine with pyart.map.grid_from_radars()

children.value: which has characteristics similar to that of the
, except that the data are stored in Cartesian coordinates instead of the radar’s antenna coordinates.
into this grid object, from the radars, using
Beforing gridding our data, we need to make a decision about the desired grid resolution and extent. For example, one might imagine a grid configuration of:
function takes the grid shape and grid limits as input, with the order
Let’s setup our configuration, setting our grid extent
Now that we have our grid limits, we can set our desired resolution (again, in meters)
Let’s compute our grid shape - using the extent and resolution to compute the number of grid points in each direction.

def compute_number_of_points(extent, resolution):
    return int((extent[1] - extent[0])/resolution)
Now that we have a helper function to compute this, let’s apply it to our vertical dimension
We can apply this to the horizontal (x, y) dimensions as well.

x_grid_points = compute_number_of_points(x_grid_limits, grid_resolution)
y_grid_points = compute_number_of_points(y_grid_limits, grid_resolution)

print(z_grid_points,
      y_grid_points,
      x_grid_points)
Use our configuration to grid the data!

children.label: Use our configuration to grid the data!

children.value: Now that we have the grid shape and grid limits, let’s grid up our radar!

grid = pyart.map.grid_from_radars(radar,
                                  grid_shape=(z_grid_points,
                                              y_grid_points,
                                              x_grid_points),
                                  grid_limits=(z_grid_limits,
                                               y_grid_limits,
                                               x_grid_limits),
                                 )
grid
Plot a horizontal view of the data

children.label: Plot a horizontal view of the data

children.value: to visualize our regridded data, starting with a horizontal view (slice along a single vertical level)

display = pyart.graph.GridMapDisplay(grid)
display.plot_grid('corrected_reflectivity_horizontal',
                  level=0,
                  vmin=-20,
                  vmax=60,
                  cmap='HomeyerRainbow')
